Summary: The proposal aims to develop a biologically plausible dynamic attention model by integrating predictive coding, dopaminergic gating, and saliency-based competition. It proposes a hybrid architecture combining spiking neural networks and rate-based networks, with validation against neural and behavioral data.
Strengths: Ambitious hypothesis integrating multiple biological mechanisms
Detailed proposed method with neural alignment and cognitive benchmarking
Comprehensive experiment plan covering validation, adaptability, disruption, scaling, and clinical translation
Weaknesses: Feasibility of integrating diverse biological mechanisms into a single model is questionable
Lacks detailed discussion on potential technical challenges (e.g., computational complexity of SNNs, integration of fMRI and single-neuron data)
Limited discussion on baseline comparisons or alternative approaches
Scientific rigor could be improved with more detailed ablation studies or stress tests
Questions: How will the computational complexity of SNNs be managed in the proposed hybrid model?
What are the specific challenges in integrating fMRI connectivity patterns and single-neuron recordings into the model?
How will the model's performance be compared to existing deep learning models of attention?
What ablation studies or critical analyses are planned to test the core hypotheses rigorously?
Limitations: Integration of diverse biological mechanisms may introduce unforeseen technical challenges
Computational resources required for simulating SNNs and rate-based networks may be prohibitive
Alignment of model parameters with empirical data may be non-trivial and time-consuming
Scalability to complex tasks may be limited by current computational neuroscience techniques
